title: Qurh, Saudi Arabia
text:
Al-Qurh, is a <a href="village">village</a> and archaeological site near <a href="Al-%27Ula">Al-'Ula</a>, north of <a href="Medina">Medina</a> Saudi Arabia. The name
القرح name translates as "<a href="ulcer">ulcer</a>s"
<a href="Qurh">Qurh</a>, also known as <a href="al-Ma%27abiyat">al-Ma'abiyat</a>, was the principal settlement of <a href="Wadi%20al-Qura">Wadi al-Qura</a> and is identified with the <a href="ruins">ruins</a> of <a href="al-Ma%27abiyat">al-Ma'abiyat</a> in <a href="Wadi%20al-%27Ula">Wadi al-'Ula</a>, eighteen kilometers southeast of the <a href="oasis">oasis</a> <a href="Al-%27Ula">Al-'Ula</a>.
History.
There are numerous references to the place in the <a href="medieval">medieval</a> Arabic sources. Excavation began in 1985.
For example, al Muqad-dasi described Qurh as "the largest town in the <a href="hijaz">hijaz</a> ...after <a href="Mecca">Mecca</a>, as well as the most flourishing and populous". <a href="al-Istakhri">al-Istakhri</a> says that "among the towns of the <a href="hijaz">hijaz</a>, Wadi al Qura is second only to al Yamama in size and production." while <a href="Yaqut%20al-Hamawi">Yaqut</a> says it was a very fertile valley "covered in villages from end to end," and indeed the modern name of the wadi still means "valley of villages".
<a href="Al-Muqaddasi">Al-Muqaddasi</a> adds it had a very diverse population.
<a href="Al-Muqaddasi">Al-Muqaddasi</a> also says "<a href="palm%20tree">palm tree</a>s skirt [Qurh]... it is possessed of very cheap <a href="Date%20%28fruit%29">date</a>s, and excellent and copious springs of water" of which <a href="Yaqut%20al-Hamawi">Yakut</a> numbers 80 springs. There is also evidence of a <a href="quanat">quanat</a> 2.5 meters below the surface.
